newsitem.title: USA: INSIGHT - T-bond reversal fizzles as support forms.
newsitem.headline: INSIGHT - T-bond reversal fizzles as support forms.

text.p: U.S. Treasury bond futures continued in a sideways consolidation pattern for a third straight day, casting doubt on the market's ability to extend Friday's downturn, technicians said Wednesday.

The 114-12/32 to 114-10/32 lows so far this week in September bond futures have formed a ridge of support coinciding with where the market was trading before the release of Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan's bond-friendly Humphrey-Hawkins testimony in July, said Brad Tyl, analyst with Aubrey G. Lanston & Co. on the floor of the Chicago Board of Trade.
That indicates the market is struggling with whether to fade Greenspan's testimony, which had been viewed as suggesting another rate tightening was not in the cards near term, Tyl said.
Tyl said a break below 113-24/32 in September bonds would dim chances for the market to snap back and resume its uptrend.
Bond futures had gained more than 10 full points since April before Friday's strong employment and purchasing managers data cut the rally short.
David Hightower, president of the Hightower Report, said he would interpret a drop to 113-15/32 as a negative sign.
"If it rolls below that, we'll assume the uptrend is over," Hightower said.
Continued high open interest in bond futures raises the question of how long bulls will hold onto their positions and should be monitored, Hightower added.

Jim Hyerczyk, president of JAH Research and Trading, said futures could bounce back to 115-19/32, approximately the 50 percent retracement of the decline from last week's 116-31 high to this week's lows.
However, he anticipated good selling interest to materialize should futures manage to claw back to that level.
The market could rebound to 116-04/32, if it can first punch above good resistance around today's high of 114-29/32, said Nick Kalivas, senior credit market analyst for Refco Inc.

He said he favored additional downward movement to alleviate the market's still-high bullish sentiment reading and was targeting 112-24/32, a previous breakout point. But the lack of momentum was a concern.
"The fact that we're consolidating and haven't got a lot of downside followthrough is making me nervous about being bearish," Kalivas said.
